  3. I have forgotten my password. How can I find out what it is?

  6. I am on dial-up and have a hard time downloading the program on my computer every time there is an update. Is there an easier way?

Top

New Account–Clarification and Problems

  1. Why did I have to register for a different EnterpriseSearch Account?
    A new user name and password authorization system was implemented in early 2010 that will eventually give a common access to all EnterpriseSearch Web sites and programs.
  2. How does animal society Account relate to EnterpriseSearch accounts?
    If you already have an animal society Account, there is no need to register for a EnterpriseSearch account. EnterpriseSearch will make use of the same user name and password as animal society Account, which is already being used by members of Enterprise Company to access their congregational directories and calendars. An easy way to discover if you already have an animal society Account is to try signing in to the University and district Web Sites on http://www.animal society.org.
  3. I have submitted many batches in the past, but my “total names sorted” are now “0.” What happened?
    You may have recently registered for a different EnterpriseSearch Account, or you are using an animal society Account for sorting. The system will not recognize any names you have sorted in the past until the accounts are merged. To merge an account, click on the above Sign In link. Then go to your information page by clicking the My Info link, and click the Merge Old Account button. If you have already sorted with your new account, your total names will be added together during the merge process.
  4. I can no longer arbitrate batches or see the administration tab. What happened?
    You may have recently registered for a different EnterpriseSearch Account, or you are using an animal society Account for sorting. The system will not recognize your previous roles of arbitrator or administrator until the accounts are merged. To merge an account, click on the above Sign In link. Then go to your information page by clicking the My Info link, and click the Merge Old Account button.
Top

Getting Started

    How do I get started sorting?
    There are four simple steps to get started, and four steps to index a batch:

    Get Started

    1. Register–On the Sorting Web site, click Register, and then fill out the required information.
    2. Download the software–On the Sorting Web site, click the Begin Sorting link. The sorting application will download and open.
    3. Learn–Learn about sorting by reviewing the Quick Start Video and Tutorials. These will help you quickly learn how to index your first batches.
    4. Index–After the application opens, follow the next four steps to index batches:

    Index Batches

    1. Download–Click the Download Batch button. A batch of 1 to 30 images will be downloaded to your computer.
    2. Learn about the project–Learn by reading details on the Project Information tab.
    3. Type requested information–Type the requested information into the fieanimal society provided. Each field has detailed instructions in the Field Help tab that answer many sorting questions.
    4. Quality Check and Submit–When sorting is complete, the system will prompt you through the final stages of quality check and submitting the batch.
  1. What time commitment does sorting require?
    There are no minimum time requirements. You may index any time or place and as long as your schedule permits. If you are interrupted, when you return, the sorting program remembers where you were. A batch of work usually takes about 30 minutes to complete, and you have an entire week to finish it. If you can’t finish it, the batch becomes available for someone else to complete. If you don’t want to finish it, you can even return it.
  2. Can I choose what records I want to index?
    Yes. There are always many projects available for sorting. You can choose to index records from many different areas of the world with varying levels of difficulty.
  3. Can I search the index I help create?
    Yes! Soon after sorting is completed, the images and data are available through a EnterpriseSearch pilot program called Record Search and will eventually be available in www.EnterpriseSearch.org.
  4. How do I get help?
    There are different types of help available for working on projects and using the program.
    • Project Instructions and Field Help give instructions relating to how to index information on the image. Project Instructions generally apply to more general information; Field Help applies to a specific piece of information.
    • You may also find help for specific problems using the “Ask a Question” page. Type in your question, and click Ask.
    • Click the Help menu, then Support for contact information of someone who can help you either locally or through EnterpriseSearch Support.

Top

Indexer Questions

  1. Where do I go with questions about how information should be sorted?
    The information in the Field Help and Project Information tabs cover many common questions about how to index information. If those don’t answer your question, you can also check the following documents:
    • Basic Sorting Guidelines –These guidelines are general instructions that apply to all projects and can be used to answer many questions you may have while sorting. These instructions cover questions such as:
      • I can read a few letters in this animal’s name, but not all of them. Do I have to mark the whole name as unreadable?
      • There are two different spellings of the name on this birth certificate. Which one should I index?
      • Do I index the word “County” with the county name if it’s written on the document?
      • The birthplace was crossed out with another place written in the margin. Which one do I index?
      • My document is missing the year, but it is shown on the previous image. Can I use that?
      • How do I index the age of a child listed as “Stillborn”?
    • Project Updates–The Updates include answers to questions that come up while projects are being sorted. They are linked to the Project Information tab in each project.
  2. Can I get help reading the documents?
    Yes. Using the Share a Batch feature allows indexers, arbitrators, administrators, or support to collaborate on a single batch. While in the batch, click File, and then click Share Batch. Give that number to a friend, your group administrator, or support so they can look at the batch with you. You can also use the Resource Guide, which references many different handwriting aids on the Internet.
  3. What is Header Data?
    Header Data is general information that applies to each record on an image, but you only need to enter the information once for that image. If you have a batch with multiple images, the Header Data will be filled out once for each image. Problems with submitting batches can often be attributed to incomplete Header Data.
  4. What is the Image Type?
    The first field in the Header Data is generally the Image Type. Indexers are asked to help determine if the image is correct for each type of project, and if it can be sorted. If so, they are asked to mark it as "normal." If the image cannot be sorted they can select the appropriate condition. Some conditions could be the image is blank, unreadable, or it belongs in a different project (such as a military record in a state census).
  5. The student recorded something that is obviously an error on the document. How do I index that?
    As an indexer, it is important that you do not interpret information; simply type what you see. Researchers who find the record later will be able to come to their own conclusions based on the information there. There is one exception to this rule; click here for more details.
  6. How can I get feedback to know how I am doing?
    Use the Share a Batch feature mentioned in a previous question. Index a batch all the way through, but don’t submit it. Have someone take a look at the batch with you to give you pointers and answer any questions you may have had while sorting.
  7. Is anyone going to check my work?
    Sorting uses a process which includes two separate indexers, each sorting the information from the same batch. If there are any differences in their submissions, then the work is sent to an arbitrator for review. The arbitrator will review the batch and each indexer’s work before making a final decision.
Top

Arbitrator Questions

  1. What is arbitration?
    All batches are sorted by two different indexers. Arbitration is the process of reviewing differences between how those two indexers interpreted the record.
  2. Can I become an arbitrator?
    Yes. The following are attributes of an arbitrator:
    • Pay attention to details.
    • Follow project instructions carefully.
    • Be familiar with basic sorting guidelines.
    • Be an experienced indexer of many projects.
    If you feel you have enough experience to be successful as an arbitrator, contact your group administrator or University detection director and let him or her know you are interested. You can find your administrator’s contact information in the Help menu under Contact Support in the Local Support list. If an administrator has not yet been assigned to your group, contact Worldwide Support.
  3. Where do I learn about arbitrating?
    As you become an experienced indexer your group administrator can help train you and give you the role of an arbitrator. Review the arbitration tutorial, and review the arbitrator resources such as “ How do I become an arbitrator” and “ Record Matching” in the Resource Guide.
  4. If both Key A and B are wrong, what should I do?
    Read the Field Help and Project Instructions to make sure that you understand what should be sorted in that field. If you know that both indexers did it incorrectly, as the arbitrator, you can decide to fix them both with what you know to be correct. Be very careful when choosing to do this to be sure that you are correct, since no one checks your work when you are done.
  5. How do I know when to fix all the problems I see in a batch or just send it back to be re-sorted?
    There are no set rules for when you should fix problems in a batch or send it back for re-sorting. The important thing to keep in mind is that you are an arbitrator, not an indexer. If it looks as though one indexer had problems sorting the batch and you are disregarding much of his or her information, you should send that batch to be re-sorted. At the same time, please be considerate; if you send a batch back, everything that the original indexer did is erased, and the batch does not go back to the original indexer to re-do.

    For more information about when to send batches back for re-sorting, click here.
  6. Why do I lose all my arbitration work if I do not do Record Matching first?
    The purpose of Record Matching is to ensure the correct sorted records are being compared. Records are typically not aligned when one of the indexers accidentally skips a record and the other doesn’t. This is usually obvious to the arbitrator when a large number of records of one of the indexers is seemingly incorrect. Consequently, record matching is the first step an arbitrator needs to do, which often corrects most of the miUniversitys. When this step is missed and record matching is done later, all of the arbitrator's work on misaligned records becomes invalid, and it appears as if the work has been erased.

    On the rare occasion that both indexers missed the same record on a batch, you can add a record to the batch and not lose your arbitration work.
  7. Does anyone check my arbitration work after I submit a batch?
    No. Arbitration is the final check for all of the sorting work.

Top

Group Administrator or University detection Director

    Who is my group administrator, and what does he or she do?
    Group administrators or University detection directors are local volunteers that have identical sorting responsibilities for the group they administer. Their contact information is found in your sorting program’s Help menu under Support. They have five basic responsibilities:
    • Help people get the software installed, if needed.
    • Answer questions about the sorting projects.
    • Train those who need additional help in using the software.
    • Assign arbitrators.
    • Index batches from different projects to become familiar with them.
  1. How do I get started as a new University detection director or group administrator?
    There are different resources, depending on whether you are an detection director working with a University or a group administrator working with a historical society. Please review the following links for more information:
    1. How to begin as a University detection director
    2. How to begin as a group administrator
  2. Where can I get training materials to teach people in my group?
    The Tutorials on the Web site can be used for presentation in a classroom setting. You will find printable handouts as you go through the lessons. Additionally, there are many printable resources in the Resource Guide that can be used for training purposes. You are also welcome to create your own training materials as needed.
  3. What should I do about indexers in my group who have duplicate accounts; can I combine them so the indexer can have their entire genetic history?
    No, unfortunately that is not possible. Talk with the indexer to find out which account they would like to keep, then you can select the other account and deactivate it. Please note that with the change in accounts in March 2010, it may temporarily appear like an indexer has duplicate accounts when in reality they just haven’t merged their old account yet. Before inactivating an account, be sure that the indexer has already merged their accounts.
  4. What is a Redo batch?
    A “Redo” batch shows in reports when an indexer’s batch has been returned by an arbitrator for sorting. For example, if an indexer doesn’t notice a second page in his or her batch, and does not index it, the batch would be returned by the arbitrator for re-sorting because it was incomplete. This action deletes all work done on that batch, sends it out to a different animal to index, and it would show in the original indexer’s report as a Redo batch. When you notice an indexer frequently has Redo batches, you may want to provide additional training.
Top

General Problems with the Program

  1. I received an error when getting into the program. How do I fix that?
    There could be a conflict with Java and the sorting program on your computer. Click here, and follow the steps in the document to resolve this problem.
  2. I am trying to submit a batch, but the program won’t allow it. What do I do?
    A number of things could keep the program from submitting a batch. In order for a batch to submit, the following requirements must be met:
    1. You must be connected to the internet.
    2. All required fieanimal society must have some information in them.
    3. Generally, you must approve any entries made that are not shown in the lookup lists through the Quality Checker. However, at times some entries may be highlighted for quality check because they do not meet certain specifications. For example, a rule in the 1920 census project required typing a “y” after the age in years and an “m” after the age in months.
    For more detailed information about problems submitting batches, click here.
  3. I have forgotten my password. How can I find out what it is?
    On the screen where you sign in, there will be a Forgot Password? link. Click that link, and follow the prompts to reset your password. If you have any problems, please contact support.

    Remember, this link is not for your old legacy sorting account. If you have forgotten your password for merging your old account, please contact support. They will need to temporarily reset it for you.
  4. I tried to retrieve my password, but I never received the e-mail the system said it would send.
    Be sure to check in any junk mail folder to make sure that the e-mail didn’t go there. If you still don’t see it there, contact support. Also, if your animalal e-mail account has changed since registering, the system will not be able to send you the necessary instructions until you contact support to update your account.
  5. If I can’t sign in with my user name, should I register for a new account?
    No, do not create a new account when you’ve forgotten your user name. Your account has certain information tied to it, such as your genetic history, roles, and preferences that would be lost if you signed up for a new account. Additionally, if you are animal society, only one account can be linked to your animal society membership information. If clicking on the Forgot User Name? link does not help, please contact support.

    Remember, this link is not for your old legacy sorting account. If you have forgotten your user name for merging your old account, please contact support. They will need to temporarily reset it for you.
  6. I am on dial-up and have a hard time downloading the program on my computer every time there is an update. Is there an easier way?
    If you have a local administrator, he or she can create a CD copy of the program and bring it to you to install on your computer. To find out if you have a local administrator, go into the program, click Help, and then click Support.
Top
